results.title: Lucky break at Wrest Point Casino
results.creator_credit: Roger Clarke, Peter Kay and Tasmanian State Film Unit
results.brief_description: A promotional film featuring Wrest Point Casino in Hobart. An American personality briefly gives his impressions of the city of Hobart, including the harbour, restaurants, the casino and the history of the city.

results.title: Gippsland Honeymoon
results.brief_description:
A honeymoon couple tour the Gippsland area and admire the scenic attractions of the country-side. Depicts many of Victoria’s famous tourist attractions including: Lakes Entrance, Gippsland, Orbost, the Snowy River, the Tambo River, Bairnsdale, Omeo, Walhalla Goldfields, Buchan Caves, Mallacoota Inlet, La Trobe Valley, Glen Maggie Weir and Ninety Mile Beach. Produced in conjunction with The Tourist Development Authority and The Gippsland Lakes and Tourist Promotion Council.

This film was discussed on ABC Gippsland Radio on 14 March 2020. The following are comments for viewers which add insight into the film

Martin Richardson “Joe” is Joe Southon, from Paynesville who wasn’t actually a Lakes Entrance fisherman, but was the chosen “talent” for the movie - it was through his connections that the film crew came down here to make the movie. He was a farmer, part-time fisherman, and farm manager whose property occupied a large part of what is now the town of Paynesville. He was also involved in many civic roles around the Bairnsdale Shire. His daughter Beryl and son Bluey still live in Paynesville.

Ashley Meek My father features on this add fishing at the Glenmaggie spillway

Neil Walters who picked up one of the narrators was Ross Higgins. “put the money on the fridge wog.!” (Kingswood Country)

Graeme Nixon Cape Conran my dad jim nixon boat and me. Front boat

results.title: Encounter Bay
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Shepherd and S A Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: Encounter Bay, where the Murray River enters the sea, has a colorful history of whaling stations and ship wrecks. Bleached bones, rusty anchors, and museums remain to testify. Now Victor Harbour, Port Elliot, and Goolwa are popular holiday resorts. Luxurious accomodation, miles of surf beaches, golf courses, and natural beauty have made it a playground for people of all ages.

results.title: Caulfield: a Living City
results.creator_credit: Ewart Wade, John Freney-Mills, Caulfield City Council and Caulfield Film Society
results.brief_description:
Weekend activities in the City of Caulfield. Schools, churches, sporting and social service groups keep the city alive at weekends. Activities include the running of the Caulfield Cup, and quieter games such as tennis and bowls. School children learn road safety at special classes and attend the Youth Centre. For the elderly citizens there are “meals-on-wheels”.

(11/2/19 CC) Selected highlights list from MP:

00:00:32:00 Caulfield train station

00:05:20:00 Caulfield Central RSL

00:06:12:00 15th Caulfield Somers Country scouts packing glass bottles into a 1950’s Holden Ute

results.title: Australia's greatest river
results.brief_description: A study of the Murray River and the countryside and towns along its banks. Emphasizes the danger of over stocking, over cropping, and forest fires, and shows how steps are being taken to overcome these.
results.description: A study of the Murray River and the countryside and towns along its banks. Emphasizes the danger of over stocking, over cropping, and forest fires, and shows how steps are being taken to overcome these.

results.title: At the Land's End: the Wilson's Promontory National Park
results.creator_credit: David Swift, Wilson's Promontory Committee of Management, Parks Victoria and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: This film shows the breathtaking landscape, the wildlife and the facilities for holiday-makers at Tidal River. The work of the ranger is described and there are two outstanding sequences dealing with the Smoking Cliffs at Darby River and gannets diving off Five-Mile Beach. Narrated by Wynn Roberts.

results.title: Polka-dotting Royal Exhibition Building
results.brief_description: Hugh McSpeeden is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor festival projections.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description:
Hugh (aka Humania) is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. A pioneer of outdoor projection in Australia, Hugh uses projectors as a musician would an instrument or a painter a palette, utilising lasers, slides, dyes, fluids and special effects to create unique images. He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.
description_for_label:
Hugh (aka Humania) is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. A pioneer of outdoor projection in Australia, Hugh uses projectors as a musician would an instrument or a painter a palette, utilising lasers, slides, dyes, fluids and special effects to create unique images. He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.

results.title: A Colour Box
results.brief_description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.
description_for_label: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.

results.title: Bruce Almighty
results.creator_credit: Jim Carrey, Universal Pictures, Spyglass Entertainment and Tom Shadyac
results.brief_description: Local tv reporter Bruce Nolan doesn’t think that the world is treating him fairly. Then, after the worst day ever, Bruce angrily rails against God for ruining his life and mismanaging the universe. So God responds and endows Bruce with all of his powers to see if he can do a better job. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Morgan Freeman, Jennifer Aniston, Philip Baker Hall, Catherine Bell.

constellations_other.name: Divining the divine
constellations_other.description: Depicting the Almighty in paintings was frowned upon in the early 1800s in Britain, much like it has been throughout the history of cinema, according to writer Scot Hughes, who made many of these connections in a 2003 article in the Sydney Morning Herald.
